awd_titl_txt: STEM Ed PRF: Understanding and Improving Undergraduate Computer Science Regulation, Performance, and Motivation Using Digital Traces and Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

This postdoctoral fellowship research project will focus on leveraging educational data mining to understand how undergraduate students in introductory Computer Science courses draw on their motivational resources and regulate learning. The study seeks to explore ways in which students’ motivation interacts with self-regulated learning. Initial findings are then expected to inform the creation of a just-in-time learning intervention designed to improve study patterns. This project also aims to increase participation for women and students of color in Computer Science by enhancing student learning and motivation which may result in greater rates of persistence and degree attainment in the field.
 
Student learning is a dynamic and context-specific process. Current interventions designed to promote persistence and performance in STEM capture student learning in broad contexts rather than in the moment students engage with their coursework. This project aims to gain a more accurate and comprehensive view of undergraduates’ learning in Computer Science using multiple data sources, including digital trace data. These data have the potential to capture the dynamic nature of student learning and motivation. The postdoctoral fellow has chosen to position her work within the framework of the “Metacognitive and Affective Model of Self-Regulated Learning” (Efklides, 2011). The fellow will then explore connections between motivation, behavior, and learning at both the task and person level and contribute new insights into that foundational theory that consider the interplay between motivation and self-regulated learning across levels of interaction. In addition, this project will use A/B methods to test an intervention created as part of the project that focuses on just-in-time, self-regulated learning support to improve study patterns. The A/B testing of motivation and self-regulated learning messages may allow for stronger claims to be made about the links between constructs and performance. Combining these methods within the same project has transformative potential for the effective use of learning analytics by Computer Science undergraduate students. 

The project responds to the STEM Education Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (STEM Ed PRF) program that aims to enhance the research knowledge, skills, and practices of recent doctorates in STEM, STEM education, education, and related disciplines to advance their preparation to engage in fundamental and applied research that advances knowledge within the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Many initiatives have aimed to improve the retention of computer science students at various universities, particularly given the critical role computer scientists play in sustaining our nation’s economy and global competitiveness. One approach to supporting students is by enhancing their motivation, specifically through (1) beliefs about their ability to complete a task, and (2) beliefs about their desire to engage in the task. Another approach is to provide self-regulated learning supports that help students apply their motivation to their studies. However, efforts to strengthen motivation alone may not lead to positive outcomes if students are unable to channel that motivation into effective learning strategies. Similarly, teaching self-regulated learning skills is unlikely to succeed if students are not motivated to engage with the course. Therefore, this project aimed to integrate both student motivation and self-regulated learning to better understand how to promote students’ engagement and performance in computer science.

 

Specifically, this project addressed these challenges by using a variety of multimodal data sources, including digital trace data from learning management systems, survey data, and interview data. Digital trace data allowed us to analyze self-regulated learning on a micro-level, investigating how students set goals, plan, monitor, and reflect in an online environment. Surveys captured and triangulated students’ motivation and self-regulated learning with the digital trace data, while interviews provided a deeper understanding of how students were learning in the course.

 

For example, using data from introductory computer science courses, we explored how both a student’s average and consistent use of self-regulated learning strategies influenced their performance, accounting for their initial motivation. We found that instructors might benefit from guiding computer science students to recognize that using more effective self-regulated learning strategies when solving coding and quiz problems can contribute to exam success. However, instructors may find it more important to emphasize consistency in using self-regulated learning strategies when solving quiz problems, rather than coding problems, to enhance exam performance. Additionally, although students’ initial motivation in computer science, along with their use of self-regulated learning strategies, contributed to exam performance, instructors may want to prioritize promoting greater use of self-regulated learning strategies over focusing solely on initial motivation, given the stronger association with performance. Understanding students’ varied use of self-regulated learning strategies across tasks like coding and quizzes is crucial for instructors to tailor their teaching approaches to support diverse student needs.

 

In another study, we used in-depth interview data to understand how students enrolled in introductory computer science courses overcome the challenges they face. Results show that lower-performing students experience more frequent and diverse learning challenges compared to higher-performing students. However, students across all performance levels use self-regulated learning strategies to overcome these challenges. These findings are important for computer science instructors and researchers, as they provide insight into how to support students’ self-regulation, which can enhance their learning and persistence in the field.

 

The combination of bottom-up data-driven approaches with top-down theory-driven approaches has allowed us to better understand computer science learning as a dynamic and context-specific process. By understanding and supporting students’ micro-level study patterns, this project can enhance students’ learning and sustain their motivation throughout their introductory computer science courses, laying a foundation for success in the computer science major. 


Last Modified: 10/09/2024
Modified by: Hye Rin Lee
